title: 115_hr1313
content: The Act may be cited as the "Preserving Employee Wellness Programs Act". Congress recognizes the importance of workplace wellness programs, such as health risk assessments and biometric screenings, to promote healthier lifestyle choices. These programs aim to reduce chronic illness, improve health, and control healthcare costs. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act allows employers to offer incentives and rewards of up to 50% off insurance premiums for participating in wellness programs. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act allows employers to offer incentives, including rewards of up to 50% off insurance premiums, for employees participating in wellness programs designed to promote healthier lifestyle choices. Congress has ensured privacy and confidentiality in wellness programs to improve health outcomes. SEC. 3. NONDISCRIMINATORY WORKPLACE WELLNESS PROGRAMS. Uniformity Across Federal Agencies: Workplace wellness programs offered in conjunction with an employer-sponsored health plan that comply with section 2705(j) of the Public Health Service Act are considered to be in compliance with relevant provisions. The workplace wellness programs must adhere to specific Acts, including the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Public Health Service Act, and the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. Additionally, the safe harbor provision of the Americans with Disabilities Act applies to these programs. The workplace wellness programs offered by employers must comply with specific Acts, including the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Public Health Service Act, and the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. Programs providing favorable treatment for individuals with adverse health factors are considered compliant with certain regulations. Workplace wellness programs offered by employers must comply with specific Acts, including the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Public Health Service Act, and the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. Programs not offered in conjunction with an employer-sponsored health plan must meet certain criteria. Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 300gg-4(j)) compliant with Americans with Disabilities Act, Public Health Service Act, and Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. Limitation on rewards for programs described in the Act. The workplace wellness program described in the Act must offer rewards that are less than or equal to the maximum amounts specified in the Public Health Service Act. Collection of information about a family member's disease or disorder as part of the program is not considered unlawful acquisition of genetic information. The workplace wellness program must comply with the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act and allow employees to request alternative standards or waivers within 45 days to earn rewards. Employers can set a reasonable time period for compliance. The employer can set a reasonable time period for compliance with the workplace wellness program, but cannot impose an unreasonable deadline for completing the alternative standard.
